title: Stanmer Park Walks

images.title: The Voice of Hassocks [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Stanmer House, Stanmer Park, Brighton. Built between 1722 and 1727 for the Pelham family (Earls of Chichester); extended in 1860. Listed at Grade I by English Heritage

images.title: The Voice of Hassocks [Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Former stables of Stanmer House, Stanmer Park, City of Brighton and Hove, England. Built in about 1725, altered later in the 18th century and in the 19th century, and now disused. Listed at Grade II* by English Heritage

images.title: Dominic Alves from Brighton, England [CC BY 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Early Spring Growth in Stanmer Park 2

images.title: Simon Carey / Great Wood, Stanmer Park, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Great Wood, Stanmer Park. The entrance via the Lower Lodges takes you through a large public park beofre reaching the village. On the western edge is Stanmer Great Wood that tops the ridge between the park and the A27 Brighton by-pass.

images.title: Paul Gillett / Cows north of Stanmer Park, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cows north of Stanmer Park

images.title: Charles Rawding / Stanmer Park, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Stanmer Park. From the University of Brighton (Falmer campus)

images.title: Paul Gillett / Farmland north of Stanmer Park, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Farmland north of Stanmer Park

images.title: Peter Bourne [CC BY-SA 3.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Stanmer Park Arboretum

description: Enjoy beautiful woodland walks and extensive open lands in this country park in Brighton. There's a number of footpaths to follow around the park which includes the village of Stanmer, Stanmer House and Stanmer Church. These would once have formed the estate of Stanmer House which is a Grade I listed 18th century Palladian building. You can sometimes pick up guided walks around the extensive woods where you can look out for bats and other wildlife. Located on the beautiful South Downs it's easy to extend your walk after you have explored the park. You could pick up the South Downs Way and enjoy a climb to the nearby Ditchling Beacon for great views over the area.
county: The City of Brighton and Hove
